tossups.question: Before this battle, the losing commander had worked on the Red Stone Road to Gist's settlement and moved his troops there before falling back to a defensive position that was unfortunately in range of the cover of the nearby forest. This side's defenders did not include the "Half King" Tanacharison but did have a company of regulars from South Carolina under James Mackay. This battle, as well as an earlier incident in a nearby Glen, would prompt the dispatch of the Braddock expedition the following year into the Ohio River Valley. De Villiers led the besieging French-Canadian forces that forced the losing commander of this battle to acknowledge Â– due to lack of able interpreters Â– that he had assassinated de Jumonville. For 10 points, name this early battle of the Seven Years' War that saw a flimsy wooden fort being defended by George Washington.

One of this man's works opens as the tenor trombone and then English horn quote from the medieval hymn Pange Lingua before the chorus enters with the Vexilla Regis Prodeunt, and that work also narrates an initiation ritual between a student and master. The body of that Hymn of Jesus was taken from the Gnostic gospels, while Thomas Hardy's The Return of the Native provided the inspiration for his tone poem Egdon Heath, and he inserted "Greensleeves" into the "Dargason" movement which concludes a suite written for string orchestra while he was music director at a girl's school. That period also saw the completion of the Brook Green Suite and a work which depicts "The Mystic," "The Bringer of Peace," and "The Bringer of Jollity." For 10 points, name this composer of St. Paul's Suite and The Planets.

One man defended this item by rebutting a man given the epithet "Alabaster" by circulating a document about seeing flowers bloom. The future of this document was secured when a five million Frank bribe was returned to arms dealer Basil Zaharoff who had tried in Geneva to negotiate an earlier version of the Armistice of Mudros. In order to prevent the downfall of the Kerensky government if Germany instituted a similar policy, Lord Curzon supported this document, unlike Lord Montagu. Chaim Weizman and Nahum Sokolow supported this, which went against the plans of Sherif Hussein and Lawrence of Arabia. It was sent to Lord Rothschild who passed it to its namesake Foreign Secretary. For 10 points, name this British document that declared support for the Zionist creation of a homeland in Palestine for Jews.
tossups.answer: Balfour Declaration of 1917 [accept reasonable alternatives for "declaration" such as "proclamation," "letter," etc.]

tossups.question: In one play by this author, SeÃ±or X is the professor of economics for the title character, a spinster. One of this author's protagonists tells her friend that she has enough to do with cooking and has no time for poetry. That character wants her son to marry Sylvia, even though he is enchanted by the wounded title character. In another of this author's plays, the title character is watched by her husband's two sisters to ensure her fidelity even though her husband may be infertile. This author created a vengeful moon that wants to take revenge on mankind by allowing Leonardo to fight a groom. The title character of another of his plays chases Pepe el Romano outside and fires a gun, which prompts her daughter Adela to hang herself. This author's Rural Trilogy includes his play Yerma. For 10 points, name this Spanish author of Blood Wedding and The House of Bernarda Alba.

Plato records Socrates arguing that the ones who first named Cronos and Rhea the ancestors of the gods must have agreed with the doctrines of this thinker. That conversation is recorded in the Cratylus, while the Theatetus argues that this thinker's major idea renders knowledge through perception impossible. This thinker offered the example of the sea being "the purest and most polluted water," to illustrate his doctrine of the unity of opposites, a consequence of this philosopher's theory of the universal principle he called logos. This man's work survives only in fragments and his most notable dictum may be a misquote of a fragment which states "Upon those who step into the same rivers, different and again different waters flow." For 10 points, identify this ancient Greek thinker who held who held that the world was in a state of constant flux.

Karatsuba proved one conjecture regarding this entity posited by Atle Selberg, and the reciprocal of this function gives a Dirchlet series involving the Mobius function. Apery's constant is defined using this function, and expanding this function out as a Laurent series around s equals 1 gives the Stieltjes constants. The Bernoulli numbers form a useful recurrence to define this function, which is equal to pi squared over 6 at 2. This function is equal to the sum from one to infinity of one over n to the s. The real part of the zeros of this function all appear to lie on a critical line, though this has not been proven. For 10 points, name this function at the center of its namesake's unsolved hypothesis about the distribution of primes.

This author wrote the lines, "nothing ever taught us to be islands," in a poem about soldiers who "holler down lions in the air." One of this writer's characters cries, "It was you who threw away my name!," in a poem about the desire to create "if not a note, a hole." This poet of "Gay Chaps at the Bar" and "Boy Breaking Glass" defied Richard Wright by publishing a poem that concludes, "Believe me, I loved you all," and begins, "Abortions will not let you forget," entitled "the mother." Lukewarm bath-water is contrasted with a dream that floats up through "onion fumes," "fried potatoes," and "yesterday's garbage ripening in the hall" in this author's "kitchenette building." This writer of Annie Allen and A Street in Bronzeville put hesitations after the word "we" in a poem about characters who "jazzed june" and "die soon." For ten points, name this poet who wrote "We Real Cool."

This virus contains several CTCF insulator sites in its genome, which prevents heterochromatin spreading along it. This virus evades immune recognition by secreting ICP-47 which interferes with the function of MHC-I. This virus' glycoprotein C binds to heparan sulfate and its glycoprotein D binds to cellular receptors. Whitlows often caused by this virus, which when in circular form expresses the Latency-Associated Transcript. This virus encodes an enzyme that phosphorylated naked thymine, and that enzyme specifically acts on drugs like valacyclovir and acyclovir, causing chain termination. In addition to causing conjunctivitis and aseptic meningitis, this virus usually lies latent in the trigeminal or sacral gangi and causes outbreaks of red lesions in response to stress. For 10 points, name this DNA virus that causes both genital lesions and cold sores.

One figure in this mythology travels through the star track, sun track, and moon track guided by the beautiful woman Den. The spiritual realm was created 3000 years before the physical realm in this system. In this system, the savior Sashoyant will be born to a bathing virgin. Wicked people are dragged by Vizaresh to the House of Lies in this system, and one group of deities in this mythology were created from divine sparks. In one story, Mashya and Mashayana emerged from a tree that grew from the corpse of the first man Gayomart. An evil figure in this myth sent Jahi to afflict women with menstruation and commanded the Daevas, while his good counterpart commanded the Amesha Spentas. For 10 points, name this mythology in which Ahriman and Ahura Mazda duke it out for all eternity, detailed in works like the Gathas and the Zend Avesta.

Teasedale and Abrahmson distinguished between universal and personal versions of this phenomenon by using attribution theory, and states that non-contingency leads to association with one of many causes. Watson and Ramey tested this behavior by having babies attempt to control a mobile via a sensory pillow. One experiment that studied this effect used curare to paralyze one group of subjects, and also used a shuttle-box apparatus which contained a low partition. Those experiments, conducted by Maier and Overmaier, divided the subjects into three groups, one of which received punishment seemingly at random and started exhibiting depressed behaviors. For 10 points, identify this behavior, exemplified by Martin Seligman shocking dogs, in which a loss of control leads to submissive behavior even when the organism can escape.

This leader inspired his cavalry with a speech including the line, "We can live with honor or die withglory! If you have the courage, follow me!", at the battle of El Roble. This man first rose to prominence as a representative of the Laja district. This man negotiated the Treaty of Lircay after defeating Gabino Gainza, and he asked Lord Cochrane to command his navies.  After a loss to Mariano Osorio, he and supporters fled to where they regrouped with another member of the Lautaro Lodge; that group was established by his friend Francisco de Miranda. After the aforementioned loss at Rancagua, he and Jose de San Martin achieved a monumental victories at Maipu and Chacabuco to secure freedom for his nation. For Ten points, name this Supreme Director of Chile, who was notably of Irish descent.

In the third act of this play, one character is gagged with gingerbread after being blindfolded and giving away all his money to a character disguised as a prince of the Queen of Fairy. In its third act, one of its main characters disguises himself as the Spanish count Diego to attempt to marry Kastril's sister Dame Pliant. Set in the house of Lovewit, this play's characters include Pertinax Surly, who tries to expose its main characters to his friend Sir Epicure Mammon, and Abel Drugger, a tobacconist who wants the title character to help his shop using magic. Most of the characters in this comedy are deceived by the team of Dol Common and Face. For 10 points, name this comedy by Ben Jonson about Subtle, who claims to be able to transmute metal into gold.

In one opera by this composer, the title character is told by his unfaithful lover that she would rather have a knife in her belly than his hands on her. The title character of another opera by this man has a husband who dies of a heart attack upon seeing his wife having an affair with her portrait painter. That opera by this man, in which the title character is desired simultaneously by the Acrobat, the Schoolboy, and Dr. Schon, includes Jack the Ripper who kills both the lesbian Countess Geschwitz and the title character. Another one of his operas has a title character who murders his lover and later returns to throw his knife into a pond then proceeds to drown in that same pond. For 10 points, name this Austrian composer of the operas Lulu and Wozzeck.

One character in this novel contests that people should not be undressed in the cold, but his argument is unheeded and he is punished by the "wolfish" Volkovoy. In a symbolic argument, the protagonist claims that the moon is destroyed each night and broken up to make stars, while Buynovsky explains the scientific truth behind the lunar cycle. After buying tobacco from the Latvian, the protagonist of this novel hears criticisms of "Old Man Whiskers." One character in this novel, Tsezar, is well educated, so the protagonist stands in line for him in order to get part of his food parcels. The title character belongs to Gang 104, under their leader Tiurin and the deputy Pavlo. For 10 points, name this Solzhenitsyn novel that chronicles the title character's time in a gulag.
tossups.answer: One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich

tossups.question: This reaction can be used to prepare the Vince Lactam from chlorosulfonyl isocyanate. Amino acid derived imidazolidinones named for MacMillan are a common organocatalyst used for this reaction, which is responsible for the synthesis of betanones. The photo-catalyzed version of this reaction is the mechanism by which UV light forms thymidine dimers in DNA. Groups on one reactant tend to form 1,2 or 1,4-adducts in this reaction, whose transition state usually contains one reactant underneath the other with its electron-withdrawing groups pointed inward in order to maximize interaction between the HOMO and the LUMO. This reaction forms cyclohexenes and preferentially forms the endo product. For 10 points, name this cycloaddition in which a diene and a dienophile react.

This artist painted a black-clothed mother and her daughters stiffly facing the viewer while the husband is facing away seated by a fireplace in a work with a light-blue background, The Belleli Family. This artist painted a work where an upside down top hat is on a drawer and a man leans against a shut doorway looking at a partially-dressed woman, which he called The Interior, but is often called The Rape. This artist painted a work where a man is reading a newspaper beside a table covered with the title substance and another work where a man in black sits next to a women looking down at the title green liquid. One of this artist's best-known works shows a white-haired man with a cane surrounded by participants in the title activity standing around, some en pointe. For 10 points, name this French Impressionist of A Cotton Office in New Orleans, L'Absinthe, and the The Dance Class.

Like Sudarshan and Marshak, and with Feynman, this man posited a vector-minus axial Lagrangian for weak interactions. This man classified kaons and hyperons by positing the idea of strangeness, and charge is equal to one-half the hypercharge plus the isospin in a formula named for him and a Japanese physicist.  One system developed by this man was vindicated by the discovery of the omega-minus baryon. That idea arranged the spin-3/2 baryons into a decuplet and the spin-1/2 baryons into an octet, from whence it got its Buddhist-sounding name. That theory led to the idea that nucleons were composed of a triplet of strongly-bound color-charged particles. For 10 points, identify this physicist who developed the Eightfold Way and the quark model.

During one election, this man was embroiled in a residency controversy when it was revealed that he spent only a month a year in his home district. In 2005, he proposed legislation that would limit the dissemination of publicly funded weather data in favor of  private, profit-based weather reporting, the National Weather Service Duty Act of 2005. This man also proposed an amendment to the 2001 No Child Left Behind Act that would insert pro-intelligent design language into the bill in the form of  the 'Teach the Controversy' education method. Gay rights activist Dan Savage led a campaign against this man due to his anti-homosexual views.  FTP, name this candidate in the 2012 Republican Party Presidential primaries whose name is a neologism for a frothy byproduct of certain sexual practices and who won the Iowa Caucuses.

Accepted at the 4th council of Constantinople, the Formula of Hormisdus was one of the earlier proponents of this principle which was notably opposed by Iganz von Dollinger. Intent to bind is one of the conditions for this principle to hold and was reaffirmed in the document Lumen Gentium. Proclamations invoking this principle are always ended with an anathema, recalling St. Augustine's statement that "Rome has spoken, the case is closed." Munificentissimus Deus, issued by Pius XII invoked this in order to declare the Assumption of Mary. FTP, Name this Catholic Church Dogma which states that when its leader speaks ex cathedra on matters of faith and morals, his teachings are always right.

One member of this house was defeated by Charles of Anjou at the Battle of Taggliacozzo. That defeated member of this house was the son of a ruler that was opposed by the powerful Ibelins of Beirut after he successfully negotiated with Al-Kamil for Jerusalem. The first king from this dynasty once had an illness personally treated by the Emperor Manuel I and formed an alliance against Roger II of Sicily after disasters at Dorylaeum and Damascus. This family's royal claims arose from the fact that their founder, a Duke of Swabia, had married the daughter of the Salian Henry IV.  The most prominent leader of this dynasty won the second battle of Iconium, was opposed by the Lombard League and failed to ford the Saleph River during the Third Crusade. For 10 points, name this Germanic dynasty that included Frederick Barbarossa.
tossups.answer: Hohenstaufen Dynasty/House [accept Swabian Dynasty before mention]

tossups.question: This city was the home of the Small Swords Society that shared the same goals as a group that attacked this city in 1861. French troops as well as Frederick Townsend Ward's Ever Victorious Army first used their heavy artillery to successfully defend this city during that attack. A sizable community, consisting almost entirely of anti-Bolsheviks, created a "Little Russia" in this port city and were rendered stateless by the Second World War. One battle in this city was instigated when a lieutenant was shot dead when trying to enter an airport. The Oyama Incident prompted reinforcements for the existing garrison in this city of three German-trained infantry divisions. One military action in this city led to its defenders being known as the 800 Heroes. That defense of Sihang Warehouse took place right beside the Foreign Concessions of the International Settlement of this city during the first major battle of the Second Sino-Japanese War. For 10 points, name this most populous city of China.

bonuses.leadin: In this man's version of the Immaculate Conception, Mary stands atop a pile of angels. For 10 points each:
answers: The Surrender of Breda or La rendicion de Breda
parts: Name this painter also known for his depictions of children and urchins, such as The Young Beggar.
Murillo was a contemporary of this other Spanish painter, who worked at the court of Philip IV and painted Las Meninas and Los Borrachos.
Inspired by a visit to Italy, this historical Velazquez work depicts Justinus van Nassau handing some keys to Ambrogio Spinola after a battle of the 80-Years War.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following questions about the Chaos in Rome after the death of Commodus in 193, the year of the Five Emperors, for 10 points each:
parts: The first of the Five Emperors in 193 was this man, an Urban Prefect under Commodus, who is believed to have conspired with the Praetorian Guard to have Commodus assassinated.
Finally settling the chaos at the end of the Year of the Five Emperors, was this emperor, born in Africa, who founded a namesake dynasty and was succeeded by his sons Geta and Caracalla.
Septimius was Governor of this region from which he was able to lay claim to the throne. It was located along the Danube and bordered Moesia and Dalmatia.

bonuses.leadin: This man's tribe was decimated in the Three Knolls massacre, and his remains were studied by Orin Starn for a book titled after this figure's brain. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this last surviving member of the Yahi tribe, the subject of a work about him "In Two Worlds".

This California anthropologist, alongside his wife Theodora, recorded several hours of interviews with Ishi. This man also wrote the Handbook of the Indians of California and discussed the idea of the culture area.

Kroeber adopted this term, also used by Herbert Spencer, to state that culture is a living thing that cannot be subdivided into individuals. Spencer believed that developed cultures were "brains" while lesser ones were vestigial.

bonuses.leadin: This work features a reversed acrostic of its author's name tying it to the word for "pure". For 10 points each:
answers: Fourth Book or Four [prompt on "last," "final," or "ending," before "Messianic"]
parts: Name this work whose third book ends with a plague and whose fourth and final book relates the story of Aristaeus and his bees. Dedicated to Maecenas, it is ostensibly about farming.
This author of the Eclogues and the Georgics may be better known for an epic poem about the Pallas, Dido, and the Trojan Prince Aeneas.

This numbered book of the Georgics is on Aristaeus's bees. This number also names the "Messianic" Eclogue where a baby who will make a Golden Age, and the Book of the Aeneid dealing with the affair and death of Dido.

bonuses.leadin: Sun Belt Water, Inc filed an arbitration claim under this agreement in 1999, and two parties to this agreement have been arguing about a duty on softwood lumber for as long as anyone can remember. For 10 points each:
answers: NAFTA or North American Free Trade Agreement
parts: Identify this trade agreement between the United States, Canada, and Mexico. Ross Perot famously stated that it would create a "giant sucking sound" as jobs moved out of the US.
NAFTA was signed by this American president. Lesser known incidents during his presidency include accidentally destroying a pharmaceutical factory in Sudan with a missile and the Whitewater scandal.
Ross Perot's running mate in the 1992 election was this vice admiral, who was the highest-ranking officer to become a POW in the Vietnam War.

bonuses.leadin: The change in this quantity is defined as the line integral of F dot dr along any path. For 10 points each:
answers: To solve those constrained systems, the Lagrangian employs this type of system in which the parameters are only functions of position and perhaps time. They are referred to as natural if time is not included.
parts: The change in this quantity is defined as the line integral of F dot dr along any path. For 10 points each:

Useful in describing constrained systems such as pendulums , this classic mechanical construct, named for its French creator, is equal to the difference between the kinetic energy and potential energy.

To solve those constrained systems, the Lagrangian employs this type of system in which the parameters are only functions of position and perhaps time. They are referred to as natural if time is not included.

bonuses.leadin: Identify some World War I-related literature, for 10 points each:
parts: This Wilfred Owen poem depicts a group of soldiers bent like "old beggars under sacks" during a gas attack, and calls the title Latin saying "an old lie".
This friend of Wilfred Owen wrote an autobiography called the Sherston trilogy, as well as a poem that details a group of soldiers failing an objective, entitled "Counter-Attack".
This contemporary English author wrote about Billy Prior, a figure she created to contrast with Owen and Sassoon, in a series of novels called the Regeneration Trilogy.

bonuses.leadin: This astronomer used to call colleagues at the Mt. Wilson Observatory "spherical bastards." When asked why, he would say that they were bastards any way you looked at them. For 10 points each:
answers: Dark Matter [do NOT accept dark energy]
parts: Name this eccentric astronomer, born in Switzerland, who partnered with Walter Baade to make many of his most significant discoveries. One famous discovery of his was made from observations of the Coma cluster.

Zwicky's most famous accomplishment was inferring the existence of this material, that does not interact with light, from the Rotation curve of the Coma galaxy cluster. This possessor of most of the mass of the universe is theorized to be made of WIMPs and MACHOs.
RAMBOs, a subset of the dark matter MACHOs, were co-proposed by Moore and this man. He names a type of diffusion damping which smoothed the anisotropies in the CMBR.

bonuses.leadin: Identify some things about controversial and shocking recent works of art, for 10 points each:
parts: Sister Wendy actually gave this man's work Piss Christ a positive review. One work in this Italian artist's Blood and Semen series forms the cover of Metallica's album Load.

Damien Hirst's The Physical Impossibility of Death in the Mind of Someone Living shows one of these creatures in a tank. JS Copley famously depicted one of these creatures attacking a boat in one painting.
This installation piece, which has settings for Marcella, Ann Hutchinson, and Virginia Wolff, attracted some controversy due to its vulvar imagery. It was executed by Judy Chicago.

bonuses.leadin: Important institutions of this religion include the Drepung and Ganden monasteries. For 10 points each:
parts: Followers of this religion follow four main schools, three of which are classified as Red Hat Sects while the fourth, Gelug is known as the Yellow Hat Sect.
In Tibetan Buddhism, a tulku has the ability to determine how this process will occur for them. Thousands of lamas do are supposed to do this, but the most famous ones are the Panchen and Dalai.

The 15th and current incarnation of the Dalai Lama has controversially banned members of this sect that worships a Dharma Protector believed to be the incarnation of a contemporary of the 5th Dalai Lama.

bonuses.leadin: Mr Harsanyi is a piano teacher who directs the protagonist to get vocal training with Madison Bowers. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this novel in which Thea Kronborg aspires to become a professional musician and eventually gets to perform in the Metropolitan Opera House.
This author of The Song of the Lark also wrote a novel narrated by Jim Burden about the Bohemian Shimerdas, My Antonia.
The title character of this Cather novel accepts death when there is a gas leak in the title abode, but he is rescued by Augusta.

bonuses.leadin: This work argues that "the philosophical problem about mental processes" arises from the fact that "we talk of processes and states and leave their nature undecided." For 10 points each:
answers: language [accept anything that mentions linguistic capacity]
parts: Identify this work which, in answer to the question, "How am I to obey the rule?" posits that "If I have exhausted the justifications... then I am inclined to say 'This is simply what I do.'"
Philosophical Investigations was written by this Austrian philosopher, teacher of G.E.M. Anscombe and author of Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus.

In multiple sections of the Investigations, including one which recalls a conversation with Frank Ramsey, Wittgenstein analogizes this human capacity to a game, and claims that philosophical paradoxes will be resolved when we understand the role of its constituent parts.

bonuses.leadin: This game takes place in Ferelden and features venues such as the mystical Fade and the desecrated Circle of the Magi. For 10 Points Each:
parts: Name this 2009 video role-playing game in which the player controls a Grey Warden combating the Blight in an original dark fantasy setting, a game which spawned a less critically-aclaimed sequel in 2011.
Name this developer of Dragon Age that recently released the MMO Star Wars: The Old Republic and is preparing for a March 2012 launch of Mass Effect 3.

Name this older Bioware roleplaying game released in 2002 set in the namesake city. It is a spiritual successor to Baldur's Gate and was followed by the expansion packs Shadows of Undrentide and Hordes of the Underdark.

bonuses.leadin: A dachshund is beaten to death in an early scene in this novel, and one of the protagonists remembers a rally for Senator Emilio Arevalo in a flashback. For 10 points each:
answers: Conversation in the Cathedral or Whatever that is in Spanish
parts: Name this novel in which journalist Santiago Zavala attempts to discover his father's involvement in a murder by asking his father's old chauffer, Ambrosio.
One of the title characters in this novel hires Pedro Camacho to help write serials for Radio Pan America. Every other chapter consists solely of the script for the serial.
Both Conversation in the Cathedral and Aunt Julia and the Scriptwriter are written by this Peruvian Nobel Laureate.

bonuses.leadin: This daughter of Thestius and sister of Hypermenestra and Althea For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this queen of Sparta and mother of Castor, Pollux, Helen and Clytemnestra who was once seduced by Zeus.
Zeus seduced Leda in the form of one of these animals. In another myth system, the children of Lir were transformed into these animals by Aoife.
Leda was married to this king of Sparta and uncle of Penelope, who was once overthrown by his brother Hippocoon. He was later succeeded by Menelaus.

bonuses.leadin: Of this work, the composer said "With it I have given all I could give. What I did I could not achieve again." For 10 points each:
answers: Organ Symphony (NOTE: accept Saint-Saens's Third but don't say that as an alternate answer)
parts: Identify this C minor symphony, its composer's third, which, though in only two movements in the score, is clearly divided into four sections and calls for a rather large instrument in its second half.
That Organ Symphony is a work by this French composer who used a xylophone to depict rattling bones in his Carnival of the Animals.
This other Frenchman wrote ten organ symphonies for actual solo organ. His most famous piece is the toccata from the fifth of those, often played as recessional music.

bonuses.leadin: The consolidated version of this document combines Â two acts passed in 1867 and 1982. For 10 points each:
answers: Canadian Constitution or La Constitution du Canada [don't prompt on "Charter of Rights and Freedoms"]
Province du QuÃ©bec or Province of Quebec ["prompt on "La Belle Province" or its English equivalent]
parts: Name this repatriated fundamental governing document, which has an amending formula with a 7/50 [seven fifty] requirement and which also contains the Charter of Rights and Freedoms.

This policy enshrined in sections 16-23 of the Charter mandates that Federal Government and province of New Brunswick services must be provided and conducted in two different ways so it is accessible to all Canadians.

The Meech Lake and Charlottetown accords tried to get this province's signature on the Constitution Act, 1982. It uses the Notwithstanding Clause to continually pass Bill 101 or the Charter of the French Language.

bonuses.leadin: The apparatus used in this experiment is commonly washed using sodium hydroxide to neutralize any previously used acid, and the solution undergoing this procedure usually has an indicator added. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this procedure in which a strong base is dripped into a solution containing a weak acid in order to measure the concentration of the acid in solution.
The buret used in titration experiments commonly has one of these twistable valves on the end. Schlenk lines and separator funnels also have them.
This is the point in a titration in which the pH of the solution is equal to the pKa of the acid. It occurs in the flatter portion of the curve.

bonuses.leadin: An amphibious landing at Inchon helped turn the tide of this war towards the UN forces, who were commanded by Douglas MacArthur. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this still-technically-occurring conflict, which was mostly ended by the creation of the demilitarized zone at the 38th parallel.
In the initial phase of the war, North Korean forces pushed UN troops back to this feature, named for a very southern Korean city. The so-called "Bowling Alley" was one segment of this feature.

After Chinese intervention in the war, the US X Corps managed to break through Chinese encirclement and get to Hungnam to evacuate. It was the last battle in which UN forces were in North Korea, and Matthew Ridgeway was made commander soon after this battle.

bonuses.leadin: A version of this anion containing the 32 isotope of its central element is commonly used in pulse-chase and autoradiography experiments. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this anion, a chain of three of which are attached to the 5' carbon of ATP. Two of these anions joined together create its "pyro" form.

These enzymes transfer a phosphate group from ATP onto a substrate, and they often act to add phosphate groups onto serine, threonine, and tyrosine residues of proteins. They oppose the action of phosphatases.

This growth factor receptor, whose ligand was discovered by Nobelists Cohen and Levi-Montalcini, is a tyrosine kinase which is often mutated in lung and brain cancers. Tarceva and Iressa are inhibitors of it
